--- title: Piriformis Muscle --- # Overview ::: {#tbl-oian-piriformis .cell message='false' execution_count=1} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ```{=html}
Muscle Origin Insertion Innervation Action
Piriformis Anterior Sacrum Apex of the Greater Trochanter Sacral Plexus Direct Br.
S1 - S2		 Hip: ER, Abduction, Extension, Stabilization
``` ::: ::: # Origin {#origin} Anterior surface of sacrum # Insertion {#insertion} Apex of the greater trochanter of the femur # Innervation {#innervation} Direct branches from sacral plexus [S1]({{< var ref-nerve-root.s1 >}}) and [S2]({{< var ref-nerve-root.s2 >}}) # Action {#action} - Hip: External rotation, abduction, and extension of the hip joint - Stabilizes the hip joint # Anatomy The [Sciatic n.]({{< var ref-sciatic-nerve.path >}}) runs superficial to all of the [deep external rotators]() except for the piriformis @bielTrailGuideBody2019. The sciatic nerve can either runs deep to the piriformis and can exit inferiorly, through the piriformis muscle belly, or superior to the piriformis. As a result, overactivation of the piriformis can lead to neurogenic pain and symptoms and is termed [Piriformis syndrome]({{< var ref-piriformis-syndrome.path >}}) # Palpation 1. Place the patient in prone @bielTrailGuideBody2019. 1. Palpate the: coccyx, PSIS, and greater trochanter @bielTrailGuideBody2019. 1. The coccyx to the PSIS is the superior and inferior bounds of the piriformis origin and the greater trochanter is the insertion @bielTrailGuideBody2019. 1. Bisect the coccyx and PSIS and place a finger there @bielTrailGuideBody2019. 1. Place your fingers along the imaginary line from the bisection to the greater trochanter @bielTrailGuideBody2019. 1. Work *through* the superficial gluteus maximus to palpate the slender piriformis muscle belly @bielTrailGuideBody2019. 1. Strum across the piriformis muscle belly to palpate its location @bielTrailGuideBody2019. :::{.callout-caution} The sciatic nerve runs through this area, so be mindful of this when palpating. ::: :::{layout-ncol="2"} ### Active palpation One can bend the patient's knee and ask the patient to perform isometric contractions against gentle resistance to better palpate the piriformis @bielTrailGuideBody2019. The gluteus maximus may be recruited during this process, but the piriformis should be more evident @bielTrailGuideBody2019. ::: # Pathologies - [Piriformis Syndrome]({{< var ref-piriformis-syndrome.path >}}) (Piriformis caused sciatica) - [Piriformis Tendinitis](#piriformis-tendinitis) ## Piriformis tendinitis {#piriformis-tendinitis} "Tenderness to deep palpation near the hook of the greater trochanter. Pain reproduced by piriformis stretch" @duttonDuttonOrthopaedicExamination2020 # Active Release Technique (ART) Active release technique for piriformis by Dr. Nick Perkins @NickPerkinsClinicalInternship - Patient in contralateral sidelying - STM to piriformis - move from hip IR/ABD/Ext into hip ER/Adduction/Flexion
